entry.title: Marvin Harrison Jr. (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that one NFL scout compared watching Marvin Harrison Jr. (pictured) to "window shopping at a Lamborghini dealership for the model that doesn't come out until next year"?

entry.title: Locumba uprising (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ...that the Locumba uprising was thought by many to be a cover for the escape of Vladimiro Montesinos, Peru's de facto leader from 1990 to 2000?

entry.title: Edward D. Boone (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Edward D. Boone was the last surviving member of his 1851 graduating class from the College of the Holy Cross?

entry.title: Surrexit a mortuis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Easter composition Surrexit a mortuis ('He rose from the dead') was scored for choir and two organs by Charles-Marie Widor, the organist at Saint-Sulpice in Paris?

entry.title: William L. Breckinridge (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that one abolitionist said that William L. Breckinridge's anti-slavery views would "disqualify [him] from political usefulness"?

entry.title: ius civile vigilantibus scriptum est (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that variations of the Latin legal maxim ius civile vigilantibus scriptum est have been used by American, European and Lesotho courts?

entry.title: Standseilbahn Linth-Limmern (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Standseilbahn Linth-Limmern, the funicular railway with the highest transport payload capacity (215 tonnes), was built to move four transformers 882 m (2,894 ft) uphill?

entry.title: Bettina Petzold-Mähr (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that before becoming a legislator, Bettina Petzold-Mähr played volleyball for Liechtenstein when they defeated Lichtenstein?
